importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Launch date of the National Education Equity Lab, which later evolved into the National Education Opportunity Network (NEON).
Year when 60% of A.P. exams taken by low-income students scored too low for college credit, highlighting a longstanding inequity in college readiness.
Year when NEON reported an annual revenue of $7.5 million and continued scaling its operations across Title I schools.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: NEON's goal to serve 1 million Title I high school students within a decade, with current operations starting in 2025 and targeting completion by 2035.

keyTakeAways: Education access and opportunity disparities persist, especially for low-income and underresourced students, despite elite universities having no trouble recruiting top athletes from similar backgrounds.

The National Education Opportunity Network (NEON) is addressing this gap by bringing college-level courses directly into Title I high schools, particularly in rural, urban, and underserved communities.

NEON's model, supported by partnerships with universities, foundations, and individual donors, connects college faculty with high school students via online platforms and teacher training, fostering college readiness and confidence.
Students who complete NEON courses are twice as likely to attend four-year colleges and persist in college longer than peers from similar backgrounds.

Despite limited funding ($7.5 million annual revenue), NEON has expanded to 33 states, serving over 40,000 students and currently operating in Jackson, Mississippi, and New York City’s Title I schools.

namedEntities.name: Leslie Cornfeld
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former federal civil rights prosecutor and education advisor who launched the National Education Equity Lab, now the National Education Opportunity Network (NEON).
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Cornfeld’s experience advising both Michael Bloomberg and Obama’s education secretaries led her to identify systemic inequities in college access for low-income students, forming the foundation of NEON’s mission.

namedEntities.name: Michael Bloomberg
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Former Mayor of New York City who collaborated with Leslie Cornfeld on education policy initiatives.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Cornfeld’s work under Bloomberg’s administration helped her understand the challenges faced by students in low-income urban schools, shaping her later focus on educational equity.

namedEntities.name: President Barack Obama
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. President whose administration included two education secretaries that Cornfeld advised.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Cornfeld’s time in the Obama administration exposed her to the disconnect between high-achieving low-income students and elite universities, fueling her belief that education equity is a civil rights issue.

namedEntities.name: Raj Chetty
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Economist whose 2017 analysis of over 30 million college students revealed that elite universities are the least socioeconomically diverse.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Chetty’s findings provided empirical support for Cornfeld’s argument that opportunity, not talent, is the barrier to college access for low-income students.

namedEntities.name: Carnegie Corporation of New York
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Philanthropic organization that provided $50,000 startup funding to Leslie Cornfeld and two subsequent grants to NEON.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Carnegie Corporation funded the initial launch and ongoing development of NEON, demonstrating institutional support for educational equity initiatives.

namedEntities.name: National Education Equity Lab
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Nonprofit founded in 2019 by Leslie Cornfeld to connect elite universities with underresourced high schools.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This lab evolved into the National Education Opportunity Network (NEON), directly addressing the gap in college access for low-income students.

namedEntities.name: National Education Opportunity Network (NEON)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The rebranded and expanded version of the National Education Equity Lab, delivering college-level courses to Title I high schools nationwide.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: NEON is the central mechanism through which elite universities are brought into high schools, offering credit-bearing courses and mentorship to students in underserved communities.

namedEntities.name: Title I High Schools
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. public schools with a high percentage of low-income students, designated under federal education policy.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: These schools represent the most underserved student populations, and NEON specifically targets them to close the college access gap.

namedEntities.name: Harvard University
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: One of the elite universities partnering with NEON to deliver college-level courses to high schools.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Harvard’s poetry class was one of the first courses offered by NEON, demonstrating the model’s feasibility with prestigious institutions.

namedEntities.name: Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Philanthropic foundation that has contributed funds to NEON.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Gates Foundation’s support reflects broader philanthropic interest in education equity and outcomes for underresourced students.

namedEntities.name: NBA
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Sports league that has provided funding to NEON.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The NBA’s investment shows that private sector actors can support educational equity initiatives, even outside traditional philanthropy.

namedEntities.name: Apollo Foundation
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Foundation that has contributed to NEON’s operations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Apollo’s support underscores the growing interest among private foundations in equitable access to higher education.

namedEntities.name: Morgan Stanley
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Financial institution that has contributed to NEON’s funding.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Morgan Stanley’s involvement signals that major financial institutions are investing in educational equity as a social and economic imperative.

namedEntities.name: Henry McCance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Individual venture capitalist and the largest individual benefactor of NEON.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: McCance’s support reflects a belief in the model’s scalability and effectiveness, and his background in venture capital informs his confidence in NEON’s impact.

namedEntities.name: Celeste Pico
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Principal of Lompoc High School, California, who introduced NEON courses to improve college prep offerings.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pico’s school case demonstrates real-world implementation and student benefit from NEON’s model in a rural setting.

namedEntities.name: Adrienne Battle
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Superintendent of Metro Nashville Public Schools, who plans to expand NEON offerings across all 12 of her zoned high schools.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Battle’s commitment to scaling NEON reflects growing adoption by public school leaders across the U.S.

namedEntities.name: Marah Rigaud
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: First-generation Haitian American student who completed five NEON courses and now attends Yale University.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rigaud’s personal story illustrates how NEON courses build confidence and college readiness in students who previously felt excluded from elite institutions.

namedEntities.name: Robert Balfanz
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Researcher at Johns Hopkins University who has studied NEON’s impact on college enrollment and persistence.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Balfanz’s data shows that NEON students are twice as likely to attend four-year colleges and persist in college, validating the model’s effectiveness.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Leslie Cornfeld, a former federal civil rights prosecutor and education advisor, identified a critical educational inequity: despite elite universities recruiting top athletes from low-income backgrounds, they remain largely inaccessible to high-achieving low-income students. This insight, shaped by her work under New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg and President Obama’s education administration, led her to co-found the National Education Equity Lab in 2019. The initiative, now known as the National Education Opportunity Network (NEON), delivers credit-bearing college courses from 17 elite universities—including Harvard—to over 40,000 students in 33 states, primarily in Title I schools. NEON’s model includes teacher training, student mentorship, and direct course delivery via Zoom, with evidence that students who complete courses are twice as likely to attend and persist in four-year colleges. Despite limited funding—only $7.5 million in annual revenue—the network has expanded to include schools in Jackson, Mississippi, and New York City, and plans to serve 1 million low-income students in 10 years. The model has received support from major foundations, private institutions, and individual donors like Henry McCance, and is being adopted by school leaders across the U.S. as a scalable, evidence-based solution to college access inequality.
title: National Education Opportunity Network Expands to Serve 1 Million Low-Income Students by 2035
